meanings.sent1: The firework seemed to displode in the night sky.
meanings.sent2: The balloon disploded with a loud bang.
meanings.sent3: The overly full water balloon decided to displode all over the backyard.
meanings.sent4: Her anger was like a volcano ready to displode at any moment.
meanings.sent5: The pressure inside the bottle was building up, ready to displode at any second.

meanings.definition: To shatter or break into pieces.
meanings.sent1: The glass vase disploded into shards when it fell off the table.
meanings.sent2: The fragile mirror disploded into tiny fragments when it hit the floor.
meanings.sent3: The clumsy cat managed to displode the delicate vase with a single swipe of its paw.
meanings.sent4: His heart disploded into a million pieces when she said goodbye.
meanings.sent5: The impact of the hammer caused the rock to displode into pieces.

meanings.definition: To cause to burst or explode.
meanings.sent1: The scientist accidentally disploded the chemicals by mixing them in the wrong order.
meanings.sent2: The loud noise disploded the silence of the night.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected joke disploded laughter among the audience.
meanings.sent4: His words had the power to displode her confidence in an instant.
meanings.sent5: The sudden burst of music disploded the calm atmosphere of the room.

meanings.definition: To undergo a violent bursting or explosion.
meanings.sent1: The old building disploded in a cloud of dust during the demolition.
meanings.sent2: The pressure inside the container caused it to displode unexpectedly.
meanings.sent3: The balloon animals disploded in a comical way during the children's party.
meanings.sent4: The news of the scandal disploded in the media, causing chaos.
meanings.sent5: The volcano disploded with such force that it could be heard for miles around.
